conbody.p: One of the most difficult questions for DITA adopters is whether or not to .

One of the impediments to
is the perceived technical difficulty in both designing the structure and coding the necessary schema files. Certainly,
is beyond the skills of a typical technical writer. However, a DITA project team should include a broad range of expertise, and outsourcing tasks that are beyond the capabilities of the team is a good strategy.
On the other hand, unless you fully understand the reasons why the base content models are inadequate for your own content, you should not .

Before designing your own
information type, you should check to ensure that there is no public domain
that would suit your needs. A number of public domain
have been developed by OASIS DITA sub-committees, industry groups, and individuals.

section.title: Rationale

lq.reftitle: Bruce Nevin, OASIS DITA Technical Committee mailing list

section.lq: It seems to me that it is common for vendors and consultants to promote the use of vanilla DITA and to counsel their customers to minimise specialisation. Yes, users should proceed cautiously and circumspectly with specialisation, but if they think that it is a DITA best practice to use only the base content models they are badly misunderstanding that guidance. Certainly, minimising specialisation simplifies implementation, customisation, and support; possibly some vendors or consultants do not adequately communicate the point; possibly some do not fully embrace it.

lq.reftitle: Eliot Kimber, OASIS DITA Technical Committee mailing list

section.lq: The base DITA content models are *NOT* authoring models and cannot be. They are the models needed to enable an appropriate range of specializations and/or local mark-up practices.
